_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

In response to the Ventura County Environmental Health Services Department directive, and as stipulated in sections 25531 to 25543.3 of the Health and Safety code, this Risk Management Plan (RMP), as outlined in the CalARP (California Accidental Release Prevention Program) Emergency Regulations, has been developed for N&H Enterprises produce cooling and shipping facility in Oxnard, California.   The purpose of this RMP is to:

     ·Increase the protection of public health and the environment by ensuring proper emergencyresponse    and mitigation procedures when handling an acutely hazardous material (AHM).

      Assist N&H Enterprises and the local governmental agencies in their communication and coordination efforts to improve facility safety while handling an AHM.

This document addresses the existing AHM system used for the produce refrigeration process at the N&H Enterprises facility.  The AHM used at the facility and for the focus of this study is anhydrous ammonia.  The devices that circulate and store the ammonia will be the subject of investigation throughout this RMP document.

     N&H ENTERPRISES  is located within the city limits of Oxnard, California, in a predominately business/industrial area, and is a produce pre-cooling, cold storage, and shipping facility.   The facility was first constructed on this site in the late 1970's and has been in continuous seasonal operation since that time.   Anhydrous ammonia is used as the closed loop system refrigerant for the single pre-cooling vacuum tube equipment at a amount of approximately 1550 lbs., and is the only acutely hazardous chemical used on the site.   The balance of the facility located on the approximate 5 acre site consists of  7,500 sq ft of Freon cooled cold storage warehouse, which is not required to be addressed in the RMP, and related office space.   

     The risks to the community from this facility would come

from an incident in which the ammonia normally contained within the vacuum tube refrigeration system was allowed to escape into the atmosphere.   In the worst-case scenario the toxic end point is located off the property within the community, the alternate release scenario was selected as the most likely event that could have a toxic endpoint located off of the subject property.   Events, which were considered possible and able to cause a release of ammonia for the purposes of the Hazard Review were:  equipment failure, operator error, design deficiency, vehicular accident, and acts of sabotage/vandalism, fire and earthquake.   It is expected that other specific events would have similar results as those listed above.   Direct contact with the released ammonia vapor by people inside the toxic endpoint is the main area of concern.

       The worst-case release scenario considered was as required, specifically being the release of 100% of the ammonia contained within the largest vessel over a 10-minute period.   The analytical results of this scenario show a distance to the toxic endpoint of approximately .87 miles, which includes mainly industrial development, agricultural land, and a smaller amount of residential area.   The alternative release scenario chosen as the most likely event involves the release of 300 lbs. of ammonia over a 30-minute period from a leaking valve or cracked pipe.   The distance to the toxic endpoint would be approximately .1 miles in this case.   Both scenarios can result in off-site impacts.

Prevention of accidental ammonia releases is addressed by the following:
               1.   System design and construction
               2.   Administrative controls
               3.   Trained operators on-site daily
               4.   Off-hours security service
               
 Administrative controls and policies to be used in the event of a release are contained in the existing " Hazardous Materials Management Plan - 1999", and the "Emergency

Response Plans and Procedures - 1999".   The major topics covered by this document are:

               1.   Emergency Contact List
               2.   Emergency Action Team
               3.   Notification Procedures
               4.   Hazardous Material Inventory
               5.   Site Plan,  Facility Layout
               6.   Personnel Responsibilities
               7.   Evacuation Plan and Procedures
               8.   Employee Training

Risk reduction steps have been and are continuing to be implemented by N&H Enterprises to: minimize the possibility of an accidental release of ammonia, and in the event of an accidental release, to minimize the effects upon the community.   The essential risk reduction steps now in effect at this facility are:
               1.   Regular daily equipment observations
               2.   Maintaining equipment maintenance records
               3.   Maintaining records of previous releases/causes           
               4.   Proper training of operators
               5.   Mechanical and electrical system controls automatically maintain the correct system      
                     temperatures and pressures, and provide safety shut-down and pressure relief in 
                     the event that the system operates out of the design limits.
               6.   Pressure vessels are equipped with high level alarm switches.
               7.   All equipment and system components are designed for ammonia service
               8.  The system appears to have been designed and installed in accordance with applicable 
                    Federal, State and local codes.
               9.  This facility currently operates under an  Emergency Response Plan which:
                        a.  Identifies the Emergency Coordinator and Emergency Contacts
                        b.  Details the Emergency Notification Procedures
                        c.  Contains procedures for hazardous material incidents
                        d.  De

tails reporting procedures
                        e.  Contains the evacuation plan
                        f.   Shows the locations of all acutely hazardous materials on-site
                        g.  Shows the locations of emergency response and mitigation equipment on site
                        h.  The system is a critical charge design.
                        i.  This facility currently operates under an Emergency Response Plan which:
                            1.  Identifies the Emergency Coordinator and emergency contacts.
                            2.  Details the Emergency Notification Procedures.
                            3.  Contains procedures for hazardous materials incidents.
                            4.  Details reporting procedures.
                            5.  Contains the evacuation plan.
                            6.  Shows the location of acutely hazardous materials on-site.
                            7.  Showsa the location of emergency response and mitigation equipment on-site.
                            8.  This facility has not experienced an ammonia release within the last five years 
                                 which resulted in the evacuation and/or sheltering in place of neighboring
                                 residents and/or properties.
             
     Mitigation of Ammonia Releases is Addressed by the Following:
               A.)  System Design and Construction
               B.)  Administrative Controls
               C.)  Maintenance Procedures
               D.)  Refrigeration System Control Hardware

     Recommended plant improvements to increase safety.            
               1.   Provide pipe labeling as per UMC and ANSI/ASHRAE standards for the vacuum tube.
               2.   Label main valves on vacuum tube.
               3.Adopt specific maintenance and construction procedures for future use.

Utility System:
This facility is connected to PG&E and is subject to possible power failures.  The

failure of a refrigeration system to operate during a power outage poses no risk of an ammonia release since loss of power simply stops the flow of ammonia within the system.   In the event of a post-earthquake fire at the site, water for firefighting and/or ammonia dilution is drawn from the city water system.  The post-earthquake functionality of the water system thus depends on the vulnerability of PG&E and the water system to earthquake induced failure, which is unknown.

Recommended Plant Improvments to Increase Safety
     A.)  Provide pipe labeling as per UMC and ANSI/ASHRAE for the vacuum tube
     B.)  Lable main valves on vacuum tube system
     C.)  Replace PRV's every five years
     D.)  Replace liquid line flex connection periodically as per manufacturers recommendation
     E.)  Diffusion tank for all pressure relief valves and sized for the complete ammonia charge.
     F.)  Seismic anchors for the tube and high side trailer to prevent dissimilar movement during
           a seismic event.

Recommended Date of Completion for the above changes:
     12-15-02
